children.value: ) products provide calibrated backscatter measurements corrected for both radiometric and terrain distortions, presented as gamma-0 power values. For users familiar with other corrected
amplitude products, these data can be used like Normalized Radar Backscatter (
Due to the side-looking nature of

, topography can significantly affect the magnitude of backscatter, with areas facing the sensor becoming artificially “brighter” (returning higher backscatter) than expected, which biases covariance measurements. To mitigate the effect of topography, an area-based
is applied to the covariance terms, normalizing the backscatter. The reference digital elevation model (
. These normalized terms are then geocoded to the output grid using area-based adaptive multi-looking.
products are projected to the appropriate

zone for their location and have a pixel spacing of 10 or 20 meters, depending on the acquisition location. They can be used directly in geospatial analysis platforms and workflows. Each product includes a covariance variable for each polarization available from the acquisition.
data product includes the following raster data sets. Complete descriptions of these data layers are available in
The primary data elements of the
product are the images of the geocoded polarimetric covariance terms. Visit
(HHHH, HVHV, VVVV, VHVH, RHRH, RVRV) are real-valued and describe the intensity of the radar backscatter for the given polarization.

(HHHV, HHVH, HHVV, HVVH, HVVV, VHVV, RHRV) are complex-valued and describe the intensity and phase between different polarizations. These off-diagonal terms are only included for quad-pol data acquisitions. Users who require off-diagonal values for dual-pol acquisitions will need to generate these layers manually from

The frequencies and polarizations available in a particular
data product will vary based on the acquisition mode used to collect the data.
Matrix of the possible polarizations available in

products. Products provided for any of the combinations on the diagonal (highlighted in dark grey) are formatted with real-valued float values, while any of the products provided from above the diagonal (highlighted in light grey) are formatted with complex values.
terms are obtained from the geocoding of the
product polarimetric covariance terms using an adaptive area-based multi-looking algorithm. The multi-looking window and number of averaged looks vary with the topography and radar geometry.
